I am Irish, I have lots of contemporary English friends and they're great guys-gals. However the English of the not-so-distant past 1900s were unbelievable a-holes. What they did to Ireland during that time - intentionally restricting food supply's from outside during a potato famine - when the impoverished Irish people's   staple food was potatoes - while also exporting the other crops and meat to be consumed in Britain, not allowing any of this higher grade food stuff to the local Irish - was tantamount to genocide. There are "mass burial graves" in Ireland, well the south west for sure, where the locals simply wheel-barrowed those who died of starvation and tipped them in. Akin to the mass graves used by the allies for the dead when they liberated Germany in WWII. In some villages in Ireland 80pc died of starvation. The English have a lot of history to be seriously ashamed of. Again modern English are fine people but your ancestors should be remembered with nothing but shame and contempt! At least Blair acknowledged and apologised to Ireland in 1999 for his ancestors behaviour. A very small gesture but better than nothing.

In my parasitology class we actually covered parasites and their relations to autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes. It's called the old friend hypothesis, essentially it proposes that our immune system requires the presence of parasitic worms to develop properly and since we live today in a world where we have access to healthcare, sanitary water and food this causes our immune system to go haywire as it is not fulfilling its functions. This theory is backed up by Immunoglobulin E (a type of antibody) which is often seen as being useless and negative because while it's function are not fully understood, it is highly associated with allergy and autoimmunity development, however it's concentration also increases during parasitic worm infections, suggesting that its role is in preventing these infections, but since it's not doing this in our sanitary world, it primes our immune cells to attack our own. There have actually been studies performed previously where chemicals secreted by parasitic worms have been used on patients and decreased symptoms of their autoimmune diseases, there are even companies providing parasitic worm therapy as alternative medicine. Could this be the future to fighting diabetes or multiple sclerosis? Maybe

Fun fact: the first ever photo taken wasn’t in 1836. It was between 1825 or 1826. By the time this photo was taken, John Quincy Adams was president of the United States, along with 4 presidents who were still alive back then, including John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and James Monroe. Also other historical figures such as Beethoven and Stamford Raffles were still alive when this photo was taken.

on this I have to disagree with you, michael.
"first picture" is a tricky thing to say becaus the issue should be: what was the first camera?

well, here we go: the Dutch (as am I) were deeply involved into lenses in the late middle ages, before or around the time the microscope et al were discovered there was a big trade in them for painters, who sat down on locations with tents around them.

trough the lens which was placed in a special opening the light beamed itself inside, projecting itself upside down. presumably it was caught on a blanc canvas, the painter sketched the most important lines, filled them in and then he had a solid enough base to continue at home. with the painting "right side up" again.

there is proof on a painting (I forgot the name) depicting a rich banquet in a room with a ceiling decorated with a very pronounced geometrical pattern.

exactly at the spot where the edges of a lens would distort the image projecting the straight lines as curved because of the lens' shape.

anyway, my point being: is a person in a black box ("camera obscura") painting a version of the outside upside down trough a lens on a canvas not also actually making a picture?

this might even lead to the conclusion that photography itself is just a continuation from the high quality point towards where painting-artist's-paintings evolved them into.

this might even imply that the sudden "change" in the quality of techniques as the use of perspective and light at the beginning of that evolution is connected to the invention of the lens.

Hmmmm... The picture of the "Horrible Cernettes" may have been the first one posted to the World Wide Web, but that's not synonymous with the Internet. The latter exists since the late 1960s (over 20 years before the WWW), albeit in a much more limited and primitive form than today, and restricted to a few universities, research centers, government institutions and military organs, mostly in the U.S. The WWW didn't exist in the Internet's first decades, but there were other ways of storing and sharing files (including pictures) since the beginning.

For example, MIME encoding (as well as now disused equivalents such as UUencode), the technology that allows one to send binary files (including digitized pictures) attached to an e-mail message, predates the WWW by many years. Certainly, there were also pictures posted to FTP servers long before Tim Berners-Lee created the WWW, and so on. Let's also not forget that in the 1980s, people were already sharing pictures on BBS's, CompuServe, etc., which were not part of the Internet back then, but were eventually absorbed by it and used similar technologies.

Moreover, the Internet was not the only large-scale computer network, and it still isn't. It's just the most widespread, most accessible and best known. For example, until the 1990s, BITNET (completely independent from the Internet) was also very popular among academic institutions, and even today there are other independent networks (international banking network SWIFT, for example, is not part of the Internet).
